[[Graeme Connors]] | website = {{URL|www.aleyce.com/}} }} '''Aleyce Simmonds''' (born 6 December 1986 in [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]]) is an Australian country music recording artist and singer-songwriter. Simmonds' accolades include the [[Telstra]] Road to Tamworth Winner in 2004. As a part of her prize Aleyce visited [[Nashville]] and recorded a successful single, "Mighty, Mighty Love". Simmonds also won an [[APRA Award]], in 2017 for Country Work of the Year, with her song "Greatest Companion".{{cite news|title=Young dance and pop songwriters dominate the APRA Music Awards |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/young-dance-and-pop-songwriters-dominate-the-apra-music-awards-led-by-flume-and-troye-sivan/news-story/d8a383e134df3841023d338ed0e920fd/|accessdate=4 April 2017}} She won Australian and National Duet of the year winner with Paul Costa for "The Way You Make Me Feel" in 2007.{{cite news|title=Tamworth's sweetheart – Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=Tamworth Country Life|url=http://www.tamworthcountrylife.com.au/tamworths-sweetheart-aleyce-simmonds/|accessdate=22 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330195646/http://tamworthcountrylife.com.au/tamworths-sweetheart-aleyce-simmonds/|archive-date=30 March 2014|url-status=dead}} Simmonds received her 7th [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] (Country Music Awards of Australia) nomination in 2017.{{cite news|title=ALEYCE SIMMONDS NOMINATED FOR SIXTH GOLDEN GUITAR |url=http://www.nbnnews.com.au/2015/12/08/aleyce-simmonds-nominated-for-sixth-golden-guitar/|accessdate=30 March 2017}}{{cite web|title=Toyota Golden Guitar Awards Finalists|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/2018-Toyota-Golden-Guitar-Awards-Finalists/|accessdate=20 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171124120549/http://www.tcmf.com.au/2018-Toyota-Golden-Guitar-Awards-Finalists|archive-date=24 November 2017|url-status=dead}} In 2014, Simmonds won Female Artist of the Year at the Australian Independent Country Music Awards for 2014. In October 2015, Simmonds was named Australian Independent Artist of the Year, Female Vocalist of the Year and awarded Best Country Single of the Year.{{cite news|title=Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=Tamworth Country Music Festival|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/Home/Media-Portal/Artists/Aleyce-Simmonds/|accessdate=26 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813021726/http://www.tcmf.com.au/Home/Media-Portal/Artists/Aleyce-Simmonds/|archive-date=13 August 2016|url-status=dead}} ==Music career== Simmonds released her debut album in 2011 and 4 subsequent radio singles and music videos for "The Keeper", "When I Say Too Much", "The Healing Hands of Time" and "Bondwood Boat". All singles except "Bondwood Boat" achieved chart positions inside top 20. Simmonds was nominated for three [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] awards at the Country Music awards of Australia, The Healing Hands of Time, written with the album's producer [[Rod McCormack]] ([[Beccy Cole]], [[Adam Harvey]], [[Amber Lawrence]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]]) being nominated for Female Artist of the Year and New Talent of the Year and "Bondwood Boat" written with [[Graeme Connors]] being nominated for Heritage Song of the year. She performed the song with Connors at the Golden Guitars. Simmonds was a finalist at the 2016 [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] Awards for APRA AMCOS Song of the Year with her song "Joshua", about her stillborn baby brother.{{cite web|title=APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Yea|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Year-/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229160347/http://www.tcmf.com.au/APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Year-/|url-status=dead|archive-date=29 February 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}} "Joshua" was awarded the No. 1 spot on the [[2YOU|88.9FM Tamworth]] Country Music Top 20 charts for 2015. Aleyce also secured No. 12 with "It Finds Us Anyway" and No. 14 with "The Greatest Companion" on the local station's countdown.{{cite web|title=Being Awarded #1 on Yearly Countdown| website=[[Facebook]] |url=https://www.facebook.com/509474795861709/photos/a.564366963705825.1073741829.509474795861709/644971785645342/?type=3&theater|accessdate=26 June 2016}} At the [[APRA Music Awards of 2017]] Simmonds won the category, Country Work of the Year, with her song, "Greatest Companion";{{cite web | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2017-awards/apra-music-awards/country/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) | [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) | year = 2017 | accessdate = 5 April 2017 | archive-date = 5 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170405173405/http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2017-awards/apra-music-awards/country/ | url-status = dead }} it was inspired by being in the studio with Luke Bona on [[2UE]].{{cite news|title=Tamworth's Aleyce Simmonds named 2017 APRA Country Work of the Year recipient|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4574397/our-golden-girl-aleyce-simmonds-takes-home-apra-honour/|accessdate=4 April 2017}}{{cite news|title=Aleyce Simmonds nominated for APRA honour|url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4532776/our-aleyce-has-eyes-on-apra-nod/|date=17 March 2017|newspaper=The Northern Daily Leader|first=Haley|last=Craig|accessdate=20 March 2019}} It's about how important overnight radio is to so many people. Aleyce was blown away by the amazing callers Bona receives throughout the night and how important the radio is to them.{{cite web|title=Aleyce Simmonds Inspiration for Greatest Companion|url=http://www.2ue.com.au/news/aleyce-simmonds-new-song-inspired-by-luke-bonas-overnight-show-20150827-gj9ka7.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812064316/http://www.2ue.com.au/news/aleyce-simmonds-new-song-inspired-by-luke-bonas-overnight-show-20150827-gj9ka7.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=12 August 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}} ==Personal life== Aleyce Simmonds was born on 6 December 1986 in [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]] and moved when she was age 12 to [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]]. At age 13, Aleyce entered her first talent quest but did not win. Then at the age of 16 she entered the Country Capital Music Association's (CCMA) Talent Quest. She was voted the best overall artist under the age of 16 and won $1,000, with which she brought her first guitar.{{cite video|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=H59SqoRER78&feature=youtu.be|title= Lee Kernaghan: The Stories, Aleyce Simmonds Part 1|publisher=YouTube|date=31 May 2011|accessdate=26 June 2016}}{{cite news|title=The Journey: Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=ABC New England North West|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/audio/2012/10/29/3620717.htm|accessdate=22 March 2013}} She started writing songs and found she had a natural country sound, and by age 15 she was playing gigs in pubs around Tamworth. While Simmonds still tours regularly, she is currently living on her parents' hundred-acre property outside of Tamworth, where she spends weekdays writing songs before hitting the road to tour on the weekends. Simmonds is the host for [[BalconyTV]] Tamworth.{{cite news|title=Tamworth shines on the world|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4058121/tamworth-shines-on-the-world-stage/|accessdate=30 November 2016}} An online music show that features bands, musicians and other variety acts on balconies around the world.{{cite news|title=BalconyTV Tamworth|url=https://www.balconytv.com/tamworth|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718104934/http://www.balconytv.com/tamworth|url-status=usurped|archive-date=18 July 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}} Tamworth is the only city in Australia that is not a Capital City that has BalconyTV. It is in association with the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]].{{cite news|title=Tamworth to join global TV network|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/News/Tamworth-to-join-global-TV-network/|accessdate=30 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130185203/http://www.tcmf.com.au/News/Tamworth-to-join-global-TV-network/|archive-date=30 November 2016|url-status=dead}} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |+ List of studio albums, with Australian positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Details ! scope="col" colspan="1"| Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:90%;"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]

scope="row" | ''Here & Now'' | * Released: 17 January 2020{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/here-now/1491216755|title=Here & Now|website=Apple Music|accessdate=4 November 2020}} * Label: Aleyce Simmonds * Formats: CD, DD, streaming | align="center" | 64 |} ==Awards== ===APRA Awards=== The [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are held in Australia and New Zealand by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] to recognise songwriting skills, sales and airplay performance by its members annually. {{awards table}} |- | [[APRA Music Awards of 2017|2017]]{{cite news | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/news/2017/april/2017-apra-music-award-winners-announced/ | title = 2017 APRA Music Award Winners Announced | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) | Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | date = 3 April 2017 | accessdate = 5 April 2017 | archive-date = 5 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170405174348/http://apraamcos.com.au/news/2017/april/2017-apra-music-award-winners-announced/ | url-status = dead }} | "Greatest Companion" | Country Work of the Year | {{won}} |- {{end}} ===Country Music Awards of Australia=== The [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-23/golden-guitars-awards-fanny-lumsden-sweeps-awards-in-tamworth/13081696|title=Fanny Lumsden wins five Golden Guitar Awards despite cancelled Tamworth Country Music Festival|website=ABC|date=23 January 2021|access-date=24 January 2021}} {{awards table}} |- | 2018 | ''More Than Meets the Eye'' | Female Artist of the Year | {{won}} |- | 2021 | "True Blue" (with [[Amber Lawrence]], [[Kirsty Lee Akers]] and [[Dianna Corcoran]]) | Vocal Collaboration of the Year | {{won}} |- {{end}} * Note: wins only ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Simmonds, Aleyce}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:APRA Award winners]] [[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Musicians from New South Wales]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:21st-century Australian singers]] [[Category:21st-century Australian women singers]] [[Category:Australian women singer-songwriters]] [[Category:People from Port Macquarie]] [[Category:21st-century Australian singer-songwriters]]
